abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Recommendations rather than lessons are
            provided, first indicating that not only did the Public
            Expenditure Management and Financial Accountability Review
            (PEMFAR) report develop a more comprehensive diagnosis, and
            more detailed recommendations - including a more realistic
            sequencing of the proposed public finance reforms - but it
            helped all stakeholders better understand the rationale for
            the reforms, as more emphasis was placed on deepening the
            reform process, on improving the structure of public
            expenditures and on modernizing the country's budget
            planning, and management instruments. The PEMFAR became
            critical to the success of the project. Moreover, the type
            of technical support national institutions need to implement
            reforms, is not just through the Bank (which should not be
            the sole institution involved in the preparation and
            financing of such program), but also the country itself
            should develop a budget reform/poverty reduction-related,
            capacity-building strategy, that should be discussed with,
            and supported by, all major donors. Finally, the protection
            of activities and expenditures, vital to improve the
            performance of public sector institutions and support the
            goal of poverty reduction, require projections of government
            revenue, based on a realistic external support:
            overoptimistic budget assumptions about available resources,
            will render impossible to adequately attain high-priority
            maintenance and operating expenditures; rather, annual
            budget preparation should be initiated at the earliest
            possible stage, preferably during preparation of sector
            strategies and medium-term public expenditure frameworks.
            The study of the protection of vital recurrent expenditures
            should also address the seasonality of both spending, and
            available resources. Finally, it is suggested that sector
            specialists need to be heavily involved in the design, and
            supervision of a multi-sector adjustment program, focusing
            on budget reform. Linking adjustment credits and sectoral
            programs probably is the best way to give Bank sector
            specialists the incentive to monitor effectively the
            progress of the reforms to be implemented in their sector.
